In addition to learning about California’s natural regions, Lexi absorbed a great deal of information about the culture of the Chumash Native Americans.  She complimented this learning with a series of explorations, which were designed to further enhance her learning.  She traveled to Humaliwo, a replica of a Chumash village, and saw what a village looked like in person.  Armed with this information, Lexi was ready to make her own scale model of a Chumash village setting, which she did beautifully, along with her group members.  Finally, in her “Chumash Story”, she created an authentic and beautifully written narrative.  We were thoroughly impressed, and often pleasantly surprised with Lexi's efforts in regards to her social studies pursuits.

After studying California’s geography, Alex learned a great deal about the culture of the early California Native Americans.  Through detailed writing, rich discussions, excellent participation in class activities, and creation of a wonderful, authentic narrative, he demonstrated a knowledge of the daily life of the Chumash people.  Through our subsequent study of the European explorers, Alex has learned to understand the impact of historical events, look at multiple points of view, examine and analyze cause and effect relationships.  We love Alex’s enthusiasm and look forward to every lesson we share with him!

Alex is a talented mathematician.  In the multiplication unit, he would sometimes rush ahead of himself and make careless mistakes. However, he has improved greatly at slowing down and paying attention to whether or not his answer makes sense.  It is readily apparent that Alex is self-motivated to achieve his personal best in math.  If he has solved a problem incorrectly, or hasn’t finished classwork, he is tenacious, wanting further instruction to help him clarify his errors, even self-selecting to stay after math group and miss some Big Yard, rather than have incomplete or incorrect work. His perseverance and determination are both commendable.  Alex clearly loves math and wants to do well.

Ava seems to enjoy the writing process and is very receptive when we make suggestions for revisions.  However, it is a struggle for her to get started on any given writing piece, as she has trouble focusing on the task ahead.  We would like to see her spending more time during the pre-writing phase, as this will assist her in both organizing and selecting content for her writing pieces.  We will continue to help Ava with strategies for following directions, as well as her organizational structure.  We have observed that Ava, when focused, makes the page comes alive with imagery!

When focused, Ava is a thoughtful and engaged book group member.  She needs to continue to work on being more specific when she provides evidence from the text to support her predictions. She also needs to make more meaningful connections as she reads.

Ava has made good progress thus far in social studies.  She was thoroughly engaged in our California animal research project on the Blue Whale.  Organizing research into categories and writing it down was very difficult for her, but she persisted and wrote an engaging report.  She also learned a large amount about the Chumash Native Americans, in a number of 'hands-on' ways, including the construction of a village scene, going on a field trip to 'Humaliwo,' and writing a 'day-in-the-life' account of a Chumash girl.

teachers=Sarah Simon, Molly McCann;skill_1205=2;skill_1206=1;skill_1207=1;skill_1208=1;skill_1209=1;skillspost=1205,1206,1207,1208,1209,794,795,798,796,797,800,898,907,909,910,801,893,895,912,913,914,911,915,916,917,918,919;skill_794=2;skill_795=2;skill_798=1;skill_796=2;skill_797=2;skill_800=2;skill_898=2;skill_907=2;skill_909=2;skill_910=1;skill_801=2;skill_893=2;skill_895=2;skill_912=2;skill_913=2;skill_914=2;skill_911=2;skill_915=1;skill_916=2;skill_917=2;skill_918=1;skill_919=2;comments=

Bee is thoughtful and engaged during social studies work and lesson times. This semester our class focused primarily on the topics of family and community systems.  She seemed to greatly enjoy our study of an African coastal community and its similarities and differences to our own coastal community through the book series Anna Hibiscus and The No. 1 Car Spotter.  Bee connected to the characters and often contributed personal feelings and reflections regarding the social dynamics within the texts. She also wrote detailed reflections and drew thoughtful illustrations in her journal, demonstrating her understanding of systems and how things work and are connected. 

In addition to this work, we went into depth about the myths and stereotypes of Native Americans, past and present, and recognized their contributions to American culture.  Bee continuously shows that she is excited to learn about other cultures and traditions and has a passion for social justice issues. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=0;submit=Save Section;

After a unit on California geography and mapping, Billi learned a great deal about the culture of the early California Native Americans.  Through writing, discussion, and active participation in class activities, she “walked in the footsteps” of the Chumash people.  She constructed a beautiful narrative and also created an artistic interpretation of a Chumash village scene.  Throughout those units and our current study of the European explorers, Billi demonstrated a strong comprehension and retention of facts, as well as a genuine curiosity and appreciation for the content we covered.

Billi understands the concepts and is a capable mathematician, but makes mistakes due to rushing.  She needs to remember to slow down and check her work. We encourage her to continue to practice organizing her work and thinking on the page, as well as her number combinations and subtraction.  As a goal for Billi, she needs to trust her instincts and learn to persevere, when faced with a challenge.

Billi is quite creative in her writing ability.  She makes an exceptional use of her imagination when she writes and is most certainly pleased with her finished writing pieces.  Billi’s finished work is always exceptionally neat and well organized; it is clear that she aims to please and cares about the quality of her work.  This is especially true of her wonderfully detailed California animal research report on the Humpback Whale.  From the very beginning of the school year, we have been impressed by the quality of Billi’s writing, and look forward to reading her fascinating, creative stories in the coming months.

Billi is also an excellent book participant.  She arrives at every meeting with her job completed to a high standard.  Of particular note, we have observed that Billi has turned in highly-detailed summaries of her reading and has regularly made connections to the reading, on a number of different levels.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Billi is very sweet, friendly, and generous of spirit.  She has a core group of friends that she associates with.  However, she welcomes and seeks interactions with any and all of her peers.   If someone needs help, she is one of the first students to volunteer.  Billi is also very responsible and dedicated to her studies.  When she turns in independent work, it is immediately clear that it has been done with a great attention to detail, quality, and neatness.  She is focused during lessons and seems to grasp new concepts as they are introduced.  Billi turns in homework on time and has made impressive strides in several subject areas.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=0;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Sarah Simon and Molly Kirkpatrick;comments=

Ethan is a kind, sweet, and thoughtful young boy.  He is well-liked by all his classmates and a pleasure to be around.  He is attentive and focused during meeting and lessons times, and shares thoughtful ideas and opinions. He puts forth good effort into his work and seems to complete his assignments with ease.  He speaks clearly and chooses his words wisely, often incorporating sophisticated vocabulary.  At times Ethan needs reminders to save side conversations for more appropriate times and is still working on resisting silliness and laughter when prompted by his peers, although a lot of improvement has been seen. He responds respectfully when redirected by his teachers, but is learning how to rely on himself to avoid these situations.

Ethan has many playmates on Big Yard and can be found running and playing with a smile on his face. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=0;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Claire is a bright, creative, positive, and dedicated child.  Her serious approach towards academics serves as an excellent role model for her peers.  Claire is naturally inquisitive and this manifests itself in the form of thoughtful comments and observations that she shares with her teachers on a regular basis.  Claire is also extremely respectful of her classmates and peers.  As a result of this, she is a very well respected member of the class.  Another area in which Claire excels is time management.  Whenever time is given for morning work, free writing, or silent reading, she does not hesitate to get on task right away. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Claire is quite creative in her writing ability.  She makes an effective use of her imagination, conferences well, and is receptive to revision suggestions.  It should be mentioned that revisions have grown less frequent, as her writing is now nearly free of errors.  She is very well organized and created a wonderful report on the White Tail Deer.  Throughout our units on narrative and thus far in our memoir unit, Claire has created detailed, mechanically sound writing pieces, which are a true joy to read! 

Claire is a passionate and thoughtful book group participant. She is a fluent reader who reads with expression.   Her willingness to explore the text for deeper meaning and ability to ask pertinent questions make her a natural leader during discussions.  Her summaries and reactions to the story on written assignments are consistently thorough and well crafted.  She is a joy to have in the group. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;comments=

Alexandra is a terrific friend in the relationships that she has. She is well-liked and has many playmates on the yard. Within the classroom, Alexandra is very quiet. She is dependent on one friend, and they tend to turn in similar work. We are helping the class understand how important it is to be unique, original, and independent in one's work, and we remind the girls of this often. Alexandra is often a listener in classroom discussions.   Therefore, we are encouraging her to gather her thoughts and express herself in this safe and positive environment.  We will continue to support Alexandra as we urge her to come out of her comfort zone, take risks, and contribute to whole-group learning. We have enjoyed getting to know Alexandra this semester and look forward to seeing her growth continue.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Claire is a strong mathematician. However, she sometimes seems to struggle a bit with self-confidence, and can be tentative in her approach to problem-solving.  We would love to see her become more vocal, seek out challenges, and become a leader in math group, as she is clearly quite capable.

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;skill_1201=2;skill_1202=2;skill_1203=2;skill_1204=2;skillspost=1201,1202,1203,1204,1084,1085,1086,1087,1088,1188,1089,1090,1091,1092,1093,1094,1095,1096,1098,1099,1100,1101,1102,1103,1104,1105,1106,1107,1108,1109,1110,1111,1112,1113,1114,1115;skill_1084=2;skill_1085=4;skill_1086=2;skill_1087=2;skill_1088=2;skill_1188=4;skill_1089=2;skill_1090=2;skill_1091=4;skill_1092=2;skill_1093=2;skill_1094=2;skill_1095=4;skill_1096=10;skill_1098=4;skill_1099=5;skill_1100=5;skill_1101=4;skill_1102=4;skill_1103=4;skill_1104=4;skill_1105=4;skill_1106=4;skill_1107=4;skill_1108=2;skill_1109=4;skill_1110=2;skill_1111=4;skill_1112=4;skill_1113=2;skill_1114=2;skill_1115=2;comments=

It seems that Alexandra has difficulty organizing her thinking to give information or retell information in sequential order, and in a cohesive manner. This is evident in her wrting.  Alexandra needs to use a story web and her personal dictionary to help her sequence a story. We continue to suggest these strategies to Alexandra.  She does better on her second draft, after we have had a writing conference.

We have seen some growth in Alexandra's reading. Her fluency has improved, however, she still tends to gloss over words that she doesn't know, and in its place, substitute a word that does not fit the context of the story. When reading with Alexandra, we suggest strategies that can help her decode the unknown word.  We practice the following strategies with Alexandra:  sounding out, covering the word and thinking about what word would fit the sentence that begins with the first sound, and slowing down and trying to self-correct the substituted word.  We also encourage Alexandra to recognize  puntutation in the passage that she's reading.  This helps her with comprehending big and little ideas.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;skill_1178=2;skill_1180=4;skill_1181=4;skill_1182=2;skill_1179=2;skillspost=1178,1180,1181,1182,1179,1161,1162,1164,1165,1167,1154,1156,1157,1158,1159,1146,1187,1148,1183;skill_1161=2;skill_1162=2;skill_1164=4;skill_1165=4;skill_1167=4;skill_1154=4;skill_1156=4;skill_1157=4;skill_1158=2;skill_1159=2;skill_1146=4;skill_1187=4;skill_1148=4;skill_1183=2;comments=

Alexandra is much more confident when she approaches a math problem.  Her private work with Meredith seems to be helping her understand CGI strategies more clearly. She works rapidly when adding number combinations to 10.  Alexandra is learning how to use the number 10 as a friendly number, and to be able to add up and down, using 10 as her base. We have been working on the same number combinations, using subtraction.  With practice, Alexandra can become facile with these combinations.  We encourage her to do the Xtra Math program, on the computer for five minutes a day.  Alexandra has more difficulty with story problems.  She has to read the problem and understand what set of operations to use. We are confident, with continued support, that she will develop strategies and comfort with this type of problem.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;skill_1205=2;skill_1206=2;skill_1207=2;skill_1208=2;skill_1209=2;skillspost=1205,1206,1207,1208,1209,794,795,798,796,797,800,898,907,909,910,801,893,895,912,913,914,911,915,916,917,918,919;skill_794=2;skill_795=2;skill_798=4;skill_796=2;skill_797=4;skill_800=4;skill_898=4;skill_907=2;skill_909=2;skill_910=2;skill_801=2;skill_893=2;skill_895=2;skill_912=2;skill_913=2;skill_914=2;skill_911=2;skill_915=2;skill_916=2;skill_917=2;skill_918=4;skill_919=2;comments=

This semester, we have been studying an African coastal community and its similarities and differences to our own coastal community through the book series Anna Hibiscus and The No. 1 Car Spotter. In addition, we went into depth about the myths and stereotypes of Native Americans, past and present, and recognized their contributions to American culture. It is difficult in certain ways to assess Alexandra's understanding of our social studies curriculum, because she does not readily participate in class discussions, and often times, her expressive thought processes are not organized or sequential. However, when we are able to have a more intimate conversation with Alexandra, it becomes evident that she is, in fact, grasping concepts. We will continue to encourage Alexandra to express her thinking, even if she is reticent to do so. We will support her in attending to the topic being discussed and to take the necessary risk to participate.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_737=2;skill_738=2;skill_739=1;skill_740=2;skillspost=737,738,739,740,1198,1199,1200,744,745,746,747,748,749,750,751,752,753;skill_1198=2;skill_1199=2;skill_1200=1;skill_744=2;skill_745=2;skill_746=2;skill_747=1;skill_748=2;skill_749=2;skill_750=2;skill_751=2;skill_752=2;skill_753=2;comments=

Claire is quite strong in social studies.  She is able to understand and retain concepts almost immediately, as evidenced in our unit on California’s geography.  Claire later learned a significant amount about the Chumash tribe in our study of California Native Americans.  All of this new content knowledge has been facilitated through activities such as discussions, hands-on activities, readings, and field trips.  Claire used all of her knowledge to create the authentic point-of-view of a Chumash girl in her “Chumash Story” narrative.

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Sherry Varon, Jan Wald;comments=

Asher comes to school each day and immediately begins to search the classroom for a particular friend.  Given the choice, he would spend his whole day with this particular classmate and we are working to broaden his circle of friends.  He is passionate about airplanes and the class pets.  We would like to support Asher in developing a wider spectrum of interests.  Asher's classmates have stated, 'Asher's heart is filled with love,' we have observed this in many ways throughout each school day.  He is beginning to raise his hand to contribute to group discussions.  His comments and questions are often insightful and increase the level of thinking for others in the group. We are pleased with the progress that Asher is making.

Ariyah came into second grade with a very limited understanding of number and how to add and subtract number combinations to 10.  She was very reliant on using direct modeling, needing counters, fingers, etc.  Ariyah was disconnected from her learning and didn't put much effort into problem-solving.  After she gained some confidence and comfort in her math group, she began to apply herself and put forth effort.  She has had successes with learning addition and subtraction combinations to 10.  Ariyah enjoys using the computer to work on the Xtra Math program.  She is competing with herself and working at a more rapid pace.  We encourage her to do this program as often as possible, and for just five minutes each time.  We are so glad that Ariyah is taking responsibility for her learning.

Chloe is a wonderful friend. She is patient and flexible and is well liked by all of her classmates. She tends to appear most comfortable and able to take more risks when working with her close friends.  We would like to see Chloe begin to expand her friendships. Chloe is very hard-working and dedicated to her learning .  She is becoming a stronger reader. She embraces her reading log, takes it seriously, and challenges herself constantly in her literature selections. Chloe has some difficulty with slowing down enough to use strategies she's learned for unknown difficult words.

As a writer, Chloe is imaginative and creative. She needs to continue to work on editing her work for capitalization, punctuation, and correct spelling.  We are encouraging her to use her personal dictionary to recognize the conventional spelling of a word when writing. At this point, Chloe needs teacher support to become aware of conventional spelling patterns. Chloe is a risk-taker in both the reading and writing process.

Chloe takes risks in using different strategies to solve problems. She functionsl independently, and works accurately to meet second grade expectations.  Chloe has shown a solid foundation in problem solving using the 'ways to ten' strategy and is developing a good understanding of place value. This is  the foundation for much of the work we do in our math group. She is able to solve double-digit problems using the strategies of 'counting on' and 'doubling'. She is able to show her work, and present her strategies in an organized fashion on paper, which indicates a fluency with numbers. Chloe stays focused and on task during math times. We look forward to supporting Chloe further by encouraging her to practice and strengthen her math facts, and attempt more complex number combinations.

This semester, we have been studying an African coastal community and its similarities and differences to our own coastal community through the book series Anna Hibiscus and The No. 1 Car Spotter. In addition, we went into depth about the myths and stereotypes of Native Americans, past and present, and recognized their contributions to American culture.  Chloe has done a beautiful job conversing about this topic in class and makes connections between herself and the world we are learning about. She has  expressed her knowledge of these studies through blockbuilding, graphing, drawing, reading, writing and conversation. Clearly, our trip to the Watts Towers and learning about Simon Rodia's lifelong journey impacted Chloe, as was reflected in her sophisticated interpretation through her December blockbuild!

Clio is an avid reader. When she has to make 'just right' book choices, she rushes to pick titles and as a result, her choices are not always a challenge for her. Yet she can read above grade level literature. As a writer, Clio has a tendency to rush through her work and not take time to independently edit before editing with a teacher. Often times, her handwriting is difficult to read.  Her sentence structure, and the placement of her sentences and paragraphs, can also be disorganized.  Clio has creative and interesting story ideas. We encourage her to pace herself and to use writing tools to help her organize her thinking.

Clio eagerly plays with numbers, shows interest in problem solving and works accurately to meet second grade expectations.  Clio needs to work on solidifying her ability to problem solve using 'ways to ten' and doubles strategies to do larger problems presented to her.  We want to encourage Clio to slow down when working on her math problems, and to read and understand the directions of a problem.  She is able to solve multi-digit problems using the strategies of counting on and counting backwards from a larger number.  She understands place value and has many of the necessary skills to be able to successfully learn regrouping with addition.  Clio stays focused and on task during math times.

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;comments=

Evan is a valued member of our classroom and we are so happy to have him at Wildwood this year! Evan has found his place with his peers on Big Yard, and can be found running and playing with exuberance. In the classroom, Evan is open and enthusiastic about learning and loves to contribute to class discussions. We are supporting Evan in improving his listening skills in the classroom, as he often needs directions repeated several times before he begins a task. We often need to redirect Evan during circle time because he continues to have private conversations. This listening issue spans across all subjects, and sometimes causes Evan to fall behind.  It is important for Evan to understand that his teachers are in charge of the class ,and that he doesn't have to monitor everyone's behavior or equity issues. We are helping him learn the importance of listening, and sharing positive reinforcement as needed. It's been a pleasure getting to know Evan this semester and we look forward to seeing his growth continue.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;skill_1201=2;skill_1202=2;skill_1203=2;skill_1204=2;skillspost=1201,1202,1203,1204,1084,1085,1086,1087,1088,1188,1089,1090,1091,1092,1093,1094,1095,1096,1098,1099,1100,1101,1102,1103,1104,1105,1106,1107,1108,1109,1110,1111,1112,1113,1114,1115;skill_1084=2;skill_1085=4;skill_1086=2;skill_1087=4;skill_1088=2;skill_1188=2;skill_1089=4;skill_1090=2;skill_1091=2;skill_1092=2;skill_1093=2;skill_1094=4;skill_1095=2;skill_1096=10;skill_1098=4;skill_1099=2;skill_1100=2;skill_1101=4;skill_1102=2;skill_1103=4;skill_1104=4;skill_1105=4;skill_1106=4;skill_1107=4;skill_1108=2;skill_1109=4;skill_1110=2;skill_1111=4;skill_1112=2;skill_1113=5;skill_1114=4;skill_1115=4;comments=

Evan has gained fluency in his reading.  He has a tendency to gloss over unknown words and substitute a word that doesn't fit the context of the story.  He also has some confusion with long and short vowel sounds. However, Evan does notice when he makes a mistake and is able to self correct.  Evan's written language is in need of scaffolding and support.  He needs to use more of his writing tools such as, story webs, word lists and his personal dictionary, to structure his story.  Evan prefers to write with a partner who is able to get the words down on paper. Although he has wonderful ideas to suggest, he still needs the writing practice, but for the sake of Evan having a finished product, we are open to Evan dictating his ideas to a teacher. We have some concerns about Evan's language processing. He needs to hear directions repeated multiple times, and words repeated during dictation. We are supporting Evan by reminding him to listen, and helping him to focus on the steps or directions given. 

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Evan shows some strong counting strategies and is working on implementing the next level of counting strategies which include learning to recognize number combinations (doubles and ways to ten for example) and learning to apply these to larger numbers and more challenging problems.  The CGI math program is going to be a great asset to Evan’s  work and ability to think about numbers, especially as his math work becomes increasingly more challenging.  We are working with Evan to stay more focused and on task, as he is easily distracted which can cause him to get behind in his work.

We are so happy to have Franny with us this year. She is a wonderful friend. She is patient and flexible and is well-liked by all of her classmates. In group discussions, Franny is pensive and thoughtful, and when she decides to contribute, it is with meaning.  We are helping Franny work through tricky classroom issues or social situations that may arise, by showing her the value of honesty, as she sometimes attempts to avoid conflict by rearranging facts. She values the Wildwood life skills and has been open and responsive to our discussions on this topic. We have really enjoyed getting to know Franny this semester and look forward to seeing her growth continue.

Evan is an emergent reader and we are so happy with his progress this year. He knows his beginning and ending sounds, and is working on short vowel sounds.  Whereas in the beginning of the year he was reading by using the pictures to tell the story, Evan now picks up word patterns quickly and uses his phonemic awareness to decode CVC words. His burgeoning skills will help him decode unfamiliar words as his reading progresses.  Evan is focused and determined during Reading Workshop, and works well with both his reading partner and in his word work group.  We love seeing how motivated he is to read his 'Just Right' books!

Evan has grown so much as a writer as well.  While he was able to tell his stories in the beginning of the year through pictures and would add letters, he now adds letters and words which correspond with the story he is telling, and he is able to read back what he has written.  During Writing Workshop it is helpful to have Evan repeat back the directions before he gets to work, so that he feels comfortable knowing what we are doing.  It has been so exciting to see Evan blossom as a writer already!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=0;submit=Save Section;

Hazel has had a successful semester in her math group.  She shows a solid understanding of counting strategies and is working on implementing the next level of counting strategies. This includes learning to recognize number combinations (doubles and ways to ten for example) and learning to apply these to larger numbers and more challenging problems. We are working with Hazel to develop a deeper understanding of place value.  This will give her a foundation that will further support  her understanding of more complex strategies.  The CGI math program is an asset to Hazel’s work and ability to think about numbers, especially as her math work becomes increasingly more challenging.  Depending on the type of problem, Hazel expresses her processes through the use of concrete materials, drawings, or written form.  

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Fletcher is an enthusiastic, friendly, and truly original, one-of-a-kind character!  He is well liked by all of his classmates and welcomes interactions with many of his peers.  He also possesses a truly unique and engaging sense of humor!  On the academic front, Fletcher turns in well-done assignments on time, cares about his work, and uses good time management skills. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;skill_1201=2;skill_1202=2;skill_1203=2;skill_1204=2;skillspost=1201,1202,1203,1204,1084,1085,1086,1087,1088,1188,1089,1090,1091,1092,1093,1094,1095,1096,1098,1099,1100,1101,1102,1103,1104,1105,1106,1107,1108,1109,1110,1111,1112,1113,1114,1115;skill_1084=1;skill_1085=1;skill_1086=1;skill_1087=1;skill_1088=1;skill_1188=2;skill_1089=1;skill_1090=2;skill_1091=2;skill_1092=2;skill_1093=2;skill_1094=1;skill_1095=2;skill_1096=10;skill_1098=2;skill_1099=2;skill_1100=2;skill_1101=2;skill_1102=2;skill_1103=2;skill_1104=2;skill_1105=2;skill_1106=2;skill_1107=2;skill_1108=2;skill_1109=2;skill_1110=2;skill_1111=2;skill_1112=2;skill_1113=2;skill_1114=2;skill_1115=2;comments=

Hazel has become a confident and avid reader. She reads and enjoys a variety of genres. Her ability to comprehend, re-tell stories, and account for details is exemplary.  Hazel's writing style is creative and artistic. She has the knowledge of sequential storytelling, and she's always eager to be involved in the writing process. We encourage Hazel to add more substantive details to the content of her story.  Hazel tends to write a straight-forward story.  She defintiely uses the correct story structure of a beginning, middle and an end.  We are encouraging her to use more yummy words, and more details, which adds interest for the reader.  Hazel is extremely capable, and we support her taking writing risks, even if the piece isn't perfect.  We discuss these possibilities with Hazel, during her writing conferences.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;comments=

Hazel is a very reserved and patient friend. She is a mentor and a role model,and is well liked by her classmates, due to her flexible and caring nature.  We would like to encourage her to begin to expand her friendships.  We see glimpses of her reaching out to others, especially when her best friend is not in the room. Hazel is a very competent and confident student. She is always focused and on task.  She works hard and does her personal best.  Hazel takes pride in all aspects of the curriculum, and always adds her personal touch to her work.  It has been a joy to get to know this semester and we look forward to watching her continued growth.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Initially, it was sometimes difficult for Fletcher to begin the pre-writing process, as he wanted to move directly to drafting.  In addition, as Fletcher cares a great deal about his writing, he can sometimes be resistant to revision suggestions.  From the beginning, however, it was clearly evident that he possessed a skill for using descriptive words and forming them into vivid, detailed snapshots.  He used this skill, along with a significant amount of organization, in his California animal research report on the Diamondback Rattlesnake.  In addition, Fletcher is quite adept at using a very personal and thoughtful voice, especially when describing topics that he is passionate about.  In fact, he has even begun to write a chapter book in his writer’s notebook!

Fletcher enjoys contributing to book group discussions.  He often offers insightful comments and makes thoughtful comparisons to other books.  In his excitement to offer his input, Fletcher needs to continue to work on waiting his turn to share his ideas.

 

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Fletcher is extremely hard working, focused, and motivated in math.  He has improved in organizing his thinking on the page and pushes himself to succeed.  He is a very capable mathematician with good number sense.  However, he sometimes has difficulty verbalizing his thinking and is resistant to feedback when he is incorrect.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;comments=

Hudson is a valued member of our classroom. He's well-liked, fair, thoughtful, and mature. His contributions to classroom discussions are intelligent and often lead us to new and exciting topics. Hudson's maturity leads him to resolve peer conflict on his own, and he is able to express himself freely. Hudson is well rounded academically and artistically, and is a joy to teach. Sometimes, we need to remind Hudson that his teachers are in charge, and that he doesn't need to be responsible for the behavior of others.  We have enjoyed getting to know Hudson this semester and look forward to seeing his growth continue.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Hudson brings a wealth of knowledge and understanding of ideas and details about a variety of texts. His comprehension and fluency are above grade level. His ideas for writing are creative and sophisticated, coupled with his ability to write in a cohesive, sequential fashion. Hudson brings an enthusiasm and a joy for learning that is contagious with his classmates and teachers.

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick, Sarah Simon;skill_1178=2;skill_1180=2;skill_1181=2;skill_1182=2;skill_1179=2;skillspost=1178,1180,1181,1182,1179,1161,1162,1164,1165,1167,1154,1156,1157,1158,1159,1146,1187,1148,1183;skill_1161=2;skill_1162=2;skill_1164=2;skill_1165=2;skill_1167=2;skill_1154=2;skill_1156=2;skill_1157=2;skill_1158=2;skill_1159=2;skill_1146=2;skill_1187=2;skill_1148=2;skill_1183=2;comments=

Hudson has a great sense of number and uses common sense when approaching challenging problems. He sometimes hesitates and has initial doubts about his ability to solve various types of problems, but once he begins, he is able to work through them with clarity and precision.  Hudson has a good understanding of place value and often breaks numbers down into their parts in order to solve multi-digit addition and subtraction problems.  He has been working on adding and subtracting number sets into the thousands, through different types of word problems.He has also been learning and exploring various strategies to solve repeated addition problems, which is deepening his conceptual understanding of multiplication and division.  Hudson frequently volunteers h shares his thinking with his peers and explains his strategies clearly using appropriate mathematical terminology.  He works at a careful pace and puts effort into making sure his work is neat and organized. He tends to keep his journal orderly, as well, showing a great work ethic. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_737=2;skill_738=1;skill_739=2;skill_740=2;skillspost=737,738,739,740,1198,1199,1200,744,745,746,747,748,749,750,751,752,753;skill_1198=2;skill_1199=2;skill_1200=2;skill_744=2;skill_745=2;skill_746=2;skill_747=2;skill_748=1;skill_749=2;skill_750=1;skill_751=2;skill_752=2;skill_753=2;comments=

Fletcher demonstrated an impressive amount of ability when we studied California geography and mapping.  Later, while studying the Chumash Native Americans, Fletcher became an explorer, artist and realistic fiction writer.  It must first be mentioned that Fletcher completed all of these tasks to his Personal Best!  He took a trip to 'Humaliwo' and saw some authentic replicas of real Chumash artifacts.  After this, he became an artist again and made a scale model of a Chumash scene.  Finally, he wrote a 'day-in-the-life' account, from the point of view of a Chumash boy!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

This semester, we have been studying an African coastal community and its similarities and differences to our own coastal community through the book series Anna Hibiscus and The No. 1 Car Spotter. In addition, we went into depth about the myths and stereotypes of Native Americans, past and present, and recognized their contributions to American culture.  Hudson has the capacity to process and synthesize information that is readily exhibited through his art, his conversation, and his working knowledge of culture and community. He is able to take abstract information and put it into a contemporary context. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Tahnee Munoz, Francesca Bill;skill_925=2;skill_926=2;skill_928=2;skill_930=2;skillspost=925,926,928,930,997,998,999,1000,1002,1003,1004,1005,1006,1007,1008,1009,1011,1012,1013,1014,1015,1016,1017,1018,1019,1020,1021,1022,1023;skill_997=2;skill_998=2;skill_999=2;skill_1000=2;skill_1002=2;skill_1003=2;skill_1004=10;skill_1005=2;skill_1006=2;skill_1007=2;skill_1008=2;skill_1009=2;skill_1011=2;skill_1012=10;skill_1013=10;skill_1014=2;skill_1015=2;skill_1016=2;skill_1017=2;skill_1018=2;skill_1019=2;skill_1020=2;skill_1021=2;skill_1022=2;skill_1023=2;comments=

Evan is an emergent reader and we are so happy with his progress this year. He knows his beginning and ending sounds, and is working on short vowel sounds.  Whereas in the beginning of the year he was reading by using the pictures to tell the story, Evan now picks up word patterns quickly and uses his phonemic awareness to decode CVC words. His burgeoning skills will help him decode unfamiliar words as his reading progresses.  Evan is focused and determined during Reading Workshop, and works well with both his reading partner and in his word work group.  We love seeing how motivated he is to read his 'Just Right' books!

Evan has grown so much as a writer as well.  While he was able to tell his stories in the beginning of the year through pictures and would add letters, he now adds letters and words which correspond with the story he is telling, and he is able to read back what he has written.  During Writing Workshop it is helpful to have Evan repeat back the directions before he gets to work, so that he feels comfortable knowing what we are doing.  It has been so exciting to see Evan blossom as a writer so quickly!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=0;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_737=2;skill_738=2;skill_739=2;skill_740=2;skillspost=737,738,739,740,1198,1199,1200,744,745,746,747,748,749,750,751,752,753;skill_1198=2;skill_1199=2;skill_1200=2;skill_744=2;skill_745=2;skill_746=2;skill_747=2;skill_748=2;skill_749=2;skill_750=1;skill_751=2;skill_752=2;skill_753=2;comments=

After studying California geography and mapping, India was introduced to the culture of the early Chumash Native Americans. She visited a recreation of a Chumash village in Malibu, constructed her own version of a village scene, and created an articulate, accurate, and engaging 'day-in-the-life' account of a Chumash girl.  Throughout the unit, India demonstrated a thorough understanding of their culture, including specific beliefs and traditions.  We have been impressed by the accuracy with which India has been able to apply what she has learned about the Chumash into writing!   

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_1193=2;skill_1191=4;skill_1190=2;skill_1189=4;skill_1192=2;skillspost=1193,1191,1190,1189,1192,387,388,389,390,362,363,364,365,368,369,370,377,378,379;skill_387=2;skill_388=2;skill_389=2;skill_390=2;skill_362=2;skill_363=2;skill_364=2;skill_365=2;skill_368=2;skill_369=2;skill_370=2;skill_377=2;skill_378=4;skill_379=2;comments=

In the content area of math, India doesn’t always see her own capabilities.  She is a strong mathematician, but the moment a problem gets difficult, she backs away. She possesses the strategies to correctly solve each problem, but sometimes needs a teacher’s reminder for which strategy to choose.  She works better when she separates herself from peers, and has learned that sitting alone is more productive than sitting with friends.  Once she gives herself a chance, she can correctly apply the strategies she knows to new problems.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Sherry Varon, Jan Wald;comments=

Laurel is a vivacious, exuberant, and productive member of our class.  She seems to love what we do, and is always a participant in class discussions.  Laurel expresses her ideas and opinions during class discussions, and supports her viewpoint with strength and pride.  At times Laurel has difficulty getting settled into a task because of her strong social connections.  She is easily redirected.  Laurel is very social and well liked by her classmates and teachers.  She is open to problem solving with a friend, and has very assertive skills in this area.  

;reader_notes=;notes=For Spring: Laurel exudes enthusisasm for life and it is contagious. She is a wonderful role model is excited about learning, is inclusive and takes on challenges with a positive attitude. ;status=0;submit=Save Section;

India is an amazing child.  Academically, she has seen some improvements, and she now seems significantly more comfortable in the classroom.  Because of this, she seems newly fortified with self-confidence.  We have seen India's focus and demeanor improve significantly; we have also seen her make strides in subjects such as math.  We are extremely pleased by these changes, are genuinely happy for India, and are committed to ensuring her continued success! 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Kate is a very energetic, enthusiastic, and happy child.  She loves to be heard and capture everyone’s attention.  Kate is admired by her classmates for her warm, social nature.  Even though this is a very positive trait, it has sometimes lead her to speak out of turn, resulting in occasional redirection.  However, Kate has been both responsible and consistent in her completion of independent assignments, both at home and in the classroom.  She has also made notable progress as a writer.  As long as Kate is making a concerted effort and focuses consistently during lessons and independent work periods, her academic successes are sure to increase in number! 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Kate is a strong mathematician, but very inconsistent.  At times, Kate can work independently and correctly solve many problems.  Other times, she doesn’t understand the strategy we’re working on, but doesn’t ask for help, so she struggles on her own for far too long.  Her effort is also inconsistent; sometimes she is strong and capable, but other times her output is low. When she’s correctly solving problems, she glows and loves to be correct.

Lucas is a highly engaged presence during Social Studies lessons.  During our opening unit on California’s natural regions, he demonstrated his ability to grasp and retain new concepts, such as mapping.  He learned a great deal about the Chumash tribe in our study of California Native Americans.  Lucas was able to successfully apply their unique cultural characteristics and integrate them into his “Chumash Story”.  With his more recent study of the European explorers, Lucas has become fully aware of the cause and effect of the encounters between the Native Americans and the Spanish conquistadors.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_1193=2;skill_1191=4;skill_1190=2;skill_1189=4;skill_1192=4;skillspost=1193,1191,1190,1189,1192,387,388,389,390,362,363,364,365,368,369,370,377,378,379;skill_387=2;skill_388=2;skill_389=2;skill_390=2;skill_362=2;skill_363=2;skill_364=2;skill_365=2;skill_368=2;skill_369=2;skill_370=2;skill_377=2;skill_378=2;skill_379=2;comments=

Lucas is a smart and capable mathematician. He takes immense pride in his successes, but struggles to ask for help when he is clearly challenged by a new strategy or concept. He is very hardworking during math group; he chooses a wise seat and uses his time effectively. When he becomes frustrated, he is quick to break down and, at times, becomes tearful. We would like to see him ask for help before he reaches this point of frustration. The strategies he possesses are effective and he is able to use them independently. He also knows his number combinations which aids in his understanding of new information. He is a genuine pleasure to have in class!

Lucas uses his vivid imagination in his writing.  He seems to enjoy the writing process and he is very receptive when we make suggestions for revisions.  It is clear that Lucas has the ability to paint a picture with his writing, through the use of descriptive yummy words and snapshots.  He demonstrated this skill in his California animal research report on the Peregrine Falcon.  Later, in his Chumash Story, Lucas made an excellent use of pacing and sequencing of events.  In this manner, the reader is immediately drawn into the story without hesitation and with a strong desire to read the remainder of the story.

Lucas is an active and respectful participant in book group discussions. His written responses to assignments are thorough and thoughtful. He is able to refer to a specific text for evidence to back up his predictions. Lucas makes strong connections to the characters in the story. We will continue to encourage him to read with more expression. He is a joy to have in the group. Keep up the good work!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Lucas is a bright, creative, and energetic child.  He is naturally inquisitive, which lends itself to consistent engagement in whole class discussions and small group collaborative work.  He has also shown recent affinities towards book group meetings and written narratives, is which he has shared many insightful comments and wonderful snapshots!  His positive, outgoing nature consistently makes Lucas a popular choice for group activities both inside the classroom and at Big Yard.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Ryan is a stellar math student. He is a determined and focused learner he likes to learn new things. Ryan does not shy away from a challenge. Whether it is a one or two-digit addition problem, he will try different strategies until he can solve it. Ryan can comfortably count on from the higher number to add quickly. He is more consistently using higher level strategies such as 'helping doubles' or adding tens. Ryan is less comfortable with subtraction. This is typical at this point of the year and we will be practicing subtraction as the year progresses. Ryan is working hard on using a hundreds chart to count forwards and backwards from different starting points. Ryan did great work with geometry and graphing. We expect he will love the upcoming units of money and measurement!

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Myles is a kind, respectful, and hard-working student.  He works very well independently and in a group setting.  He is quite focused during lessons and is both considerate and cooperative!  Myles turns in his homework on time; he always makes sure the requirements have been met.  We have sometimes found that he is easily intimidated by new material, especially in math, when he does not comprehend it immediately.  Ultimately, he is able to grasp the new concepts, but the initial apprehension serves as an obstacle, which is sometimes difficult for him to overcome.  We have been helping him to overcome this tendency and have already noticed signs of improvement.

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Myles seems to be enjoying the writing process and has adapted to the challenges presented by the fourth grade writing curriculum; he is also very receptive when we make suggestions for revisions.  We would like to see Myles pushing himself a bit more on his writing assignments, to achieve an even higher standard of work.  In class, he sometimes struggles initially with meeting length requirements; we have often told him to go back and add more details.  However, during his California animal research project on the Puma, Myles was able to gather and organize a significant amount of information, which ultimately resulted in a richly-detailed report!

Myles has been an enthusiastic, welcome presence in our book group meetings.  He has demonstrated a particular affinity for retelling major events from the story!  He has also connected well to the characters to which he has been introduced.  Even with those ample reserves of enthusiasm, Myles is very respectful of other students; he monitors his own airtime and takes turns nicely with his fellow group members.  Completing his impressive repertoire are his weekly assignments, which are always well done and turned in on time.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_1193=2;skill_1191=4;skill_1190=2;skill_1189=4;skill_1192=2;skillspost=1193,1191,1190,1189,1192,387,388,389,390,362,363,364,365,368,369,370,377,378,379;skill_387=2;skill_388=2;skill_389=2;skill_390=2;skill_362=2;skill_363=2;skill_364=2;skill_365=2;skill_368=2;skill_369=2;skill_370=2;skill_377=2;skill_378=2;skill_379=2;comments=

Myles is a very hard working mathematician. He stays focused during math group, participates well, and is determined to solve every problem in the time given. He is quick to grasp new concepts.  However, he steps away from challenges, and we would like to see his confidence grow.  He is capable of taking on a challenge, but it is uncomfortable, and he struggles to persevere.  In addition, he sometimes rushes and makes careless errors.  However, we are happy to report that Myles has strong number sense and his mastery of math facts has improved!

Myles is an enthusiastic and curious presence in Social Studies.  He has learned about California’s natural regions, the Chumash Native Americans, and Spanish explorers.  His Chumash story is an accurate, articulate synthesis of his knowledge of this fascinating tribe’s culture.  With his more recent study of the European explorers, Myles has become fully aware of this cataclysmic clash of cultures, as well as the resulting consequences.  His questions are also rich and beyond his years in their depth!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_737=2;skill_738=1;skill_739=2;skill_740=2;skillspost=737,738,739,740,1198,1199,1200,744,745,746,747,748,749,750,751,752,753;skill_1198=2;skill_1199=2;skill_1200=1;skill_744=1;skill_745=2;skill_746=2;skill_747=2;skill_748=1;skill_749=2;skill_750=2;skill_751=2;skill_752=2;skill_753=2;comments=

Noah seemed to enjoy his study of California’s natural regions and the Chumash Native Americans.  He went on a field trip to 'Humaliwo”, a Chumash village replica, where he saw life-size recreations of artifacts that he had been studying.  He drew inspiration from that visit and created a scale model of a Chumash village setting.  Finally, he used everything he had learned to write a 'day-in-the-life' account of a Chumash boy.  More recently, he has been a very curious and frequent participant in our discussions on the European explorers.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_1193=1;skill_1191=1;skill_1190=2;skill_1189=1;skill_1192=2;skillspost=1193,1191,1190,1189,1192,387,388,389,390,362,363,364,365,368,369,370,377,378,379;skill_387=1;skill_388=1;skill_389=1;skill_390=1;skill_362=1;skill_363=1;skill_364=1;skill_365=2;skill_368=2;skill_369=2;skill_370=2;skill_377=1;skill_378=1;skill_379=1;comments=

Noah is an outstanding math student.  Noah is able to grasp advanced concepts; his ability to break apart numbers is just as impressive as his oral explanations.  It could honestly be said that Noah could probably do a fine job of teaching the class, with one small exception. When Noah is describing his work to the class, he has to be reminded to speak up, as he sometimes speaks under his breath and is hard to hear.  Even so, his explanations are very thorough and articulate and his work is always shown and largely accurate.  In this manner, Noah is a great example for the other students, as some of them do not show their work.  We commend Noah for his enthusiasm and dedication towards math and look forward to each lesson with him!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_880=2;skill_881=2;skill_882=2;skill_995=2;skill_883=2;skillspost=880,881,882,995,883,1194,1195,1196,1197,896,897,899,900,901,902,903,904,905,906,908,872,873,874,875,876,877,878,879,866,867,868,869,870,871,857,858,859,860,861,862,863,864,865;skill_1194=2;skill_1195=2;skill_1196=2;skill_1197=2;skill_896=2;skill_897=2;skill_899=2;skill_900=2;skill_901=2;skill_902=2;skill_903=2;skill_904=2;skill_905=2;skill_906=2;skill_908=2;skill_872=2;skill_873=2;skill_874=2;skill_875=2;skill_876=2;skill_877=2;skill_878=2;skill_879=2;skill_866=2;skill_867=2;skill_868=2;skill_869=2;skill_870=2;skill_871=1;skill_857=2;skill_858=2;skill_859=2;skill_860=2;skill_861=2;skill_862=2;skill_863=2;skill_864=2;skill_865=2;comments=

Noah’s writing skills have improved since the beginning of the school year.  Creative writing is something that is a work in progress for Noah; it is especially difficult for him to absorb even the most delicately worded suggestions for revision.  However, we noticed that Noah had a penchant for strictly defined writing formats, such as research.  We surmise that this was because this format had specific “bulleted” categories, which, once completed, needed to be edited primarily for mechanics; the writing process had a more technical, regimented process, which he enjoyed.  In fact, Noah improved his writing skills while completing his animal research report on the Bighorn Sheep.  Noah was able to categorize information with ease, taking copious amounts of relevant notes in the process.  The result was a very detailed, well-organized piece of writing.

We enjoyed Noah's presence in book group meetings; he always participated frequently and was also very considerate of others, when it was their turn to share ideas.  He often made accurate predictions and connections of his own, whose origins could be clearly traced back to the text.  We also noticed that Noah pro;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Noah is responsible, enthusiastic, and passionate.  He is well liked by all of his classmates.  Noah has a core group of friends, but welcomes interactions with fellow peers.  Noah is also very responsible about recording his assignments daily.  He turns in well-done assignments on time, cares about his work, and uses good time management skills.  Whenever time is given for morning work, free writing, or silent reading, he does not hesitate to get on task right away.  As a goal for Noah, we would like to see him become more receptive to revision suggestions, when they are given.  Receptiveness and being able to hear and respond to constructive comments are life skills; we would like to see Noah place a greater emphasis on this important area and know that he can be successful if he so desires.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Owen has a tremendous amount of respect for the school environment.  This includes his teachers, his classmates, his peers, and the school grounds.  As he is extremely courteous of his classmates, he can be grouped with any one of them during group activities.  Owen is also very responsible and dedicated to his academic pursuits.  Not surprisingly, both his independent class work and homework are consistently completed on time.

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Owen has always expressed himself well, both orally and in written form.  He demonstrates good skills in the mechanics of writing as well as an impressive vocabulary.  Owen has always conferenced well with us and readily accepts our notes and suggestions for revision.  He also applies the writing tools and literary techniques, which are modeled and subsequently learned in class, to his own work.  During the process of compiling research for his California animal research project on the Sea Otter, Owen was very focused on his acquisition of facts from the resources in the library.  The resulting report was beautifully synthesized in its accuracy and detail!

Owen is a thoughtful and focused contributor to book group discussions. He thinks deeply about the story and is able to refer to the text to find pertinent evidence to support his predictions. His homework is completed on time and is clearly written. Owen consistently keeps post-it notes in his book and comes to meetings prepared. It is a pleasure to have him in the group!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_1193=2;skill_1191=2;skill_1190=2;skill_1189=2;skill_1192=1;skillspost=1193,1191,1190,1189,1192,387,388,389,390,362,363,364,365,368,369,370,377,378,379;skill_387=2;skill_388=2;skill_389=2;skill_390=2;skill_362=2;skill_363=2;skill_364=2;skill_365=2;skill_368=2;skill_369=2;skill_370=2;skill_377=2;skill_378=2;skill_379=2;comments=

Owen’s organizational issues caused him some problems in multiplication, but we used some strategies (like turning lined paper sideways) to help him. So far, he is thriving in our division unit.  It’s been wonderful to see this shift in him. We’d love to see Owen be more vocal in math group. He is a quiet, yet strong presence. 

 

 

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;skill_737=2;skill_738=2;skill_739=2;skill_740=2;skillspost=737,738,739,740,1198,1199,1200,744,745,746,747,748,749,750,751,752,753;skill_1198=1;skill_1199=2;skill_1200=1;skill_744=1;skill_745=2;skill_746=2;skill_747=2;skill_748=2;skill_749=2;skill_750=2;skill_751=2;skill_752=2;skill_753=2;comments=

Owen was very actively involved in our study of the regions of California, our focus on the Chumash tribe of California Native Americans, and our recent emphasis on the European explorers.  When we began our study of the Chumash, Owen seemed quite fascinated by their way of life, especially in their use of nature to be self-sufficient.  Along with his classmates, he created a village scene, using different artistic mediums.  He is engaged and often comes up with excellent questions.  His writing reached new heights in its sophistication and depth during the construction of his “Chumash Story”.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

After a brief foray into California’s natural regions, Quincy learned a great deal about the early California Native Americans.  Through writing, discussions, and enthusiastic participation in a wide range of class activities, Quincy demonstrated her ability to appreciate the culture of the Chumash tribe.  She integrated her new content knowledge to construct an engaging, highly detailed account of a day-in-the-life of a Chumash child.  She has demonstrated the same amount of enthusiasm in our current unit on European explorers; we look forward to each lesson with Quincy!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

As a writer, Quincy impressed us early in the school year with her organization and summarizing skills, especially when compiling information for her California animal research report on the Bobcat.  Along with her fellow classmates, Quincy has been learning about the writing genres of narrative and memoir.  We have found Quincy’s writing to be mechanically sound, mostly free of spelling errors, and very well organized.  We are happy to add that she is very receptive to revision suggestions, when they are given to her in writer’s conferences. 

In book group, Quincy was a very enthusiastic participant.  This was certainly the case when she took special care to thoughtfully prepare her book group assignments.  During our meetings, Quincy exhibited good story comprehension and was always respectful of other students' ideas.  We enjoyed every book group meeting we had with Quincy!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Quincy is responsible, friendly, and full of spirit!  Quincy has found that she shares similar interests with other members of the class; she is happy and very engaged.  Quincy is also very responsible about completing her assignments and has a commendable work ethic.  She turns in well-done assignments on time, cares about her work, and uses good time management skills.

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Rocco is quiet, friendly, and extremely respectful.  He is also well liked by his classmates.  Rocco has found that he shares similar interests with other members of the class and this has certainly helped him transition socially in the classroom.  He has become somewhat more confident academically since the beginning of the year and now contributes more frequently and willingly in meeting.  Of course, we will continue to support Rocco writing, his area of greatest academic need, but are encouraged by his increased confidence and recent progress.

 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

When focused and motivated, he is able to solve problems in a very efficient way and organize work on the page.  When pressed, Rocco understands concepts, but often stops working as soon as his teachers walk away.  Rocco hesitates to ask for help; for the majority of math group, he needed someone to sit directly next to him to work.  Very recently, he has been extremely focused/motivated.  As a goal for Rocco, he needs to continue to work on automaticity with number combinations.

Social studies started up with a bang for Rocco, as the process of writing his California animal research report on the Orca was quite challenging for him.  He struggled with categorizing information and synthesizing that information into clear paragraphs.  However, with a significant amount of assistance, he was able to produce an informative report.  While studying the Chumash Native Americans, Rocco was also able to start connecting to the people he was studying.  Even though it is still a work in progress, due to the challenge posed by the many steps involved, Rocco has been writing an engaging, accurate account of a day-in-the-life of a Chumash boy.  He also seems deeply engaged and interested in our current unit on the European explorers.   

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Sam exhibited a significant amount of interest and ability in both our units on California’s geography and the Chumash Native Americans.  After learning all about their culture, Sam embarked on a number of projects.  Sam took a field trip to Malibu and visited a replica of a Chumash village in Malibu.  Back in the classroom, he created a replica of the Chumash dwellings he saw during the trip.  Finally, Sam created a 'day-in-the life' account of a Chumash boy.  More recently, Sam has shown quite a bit of interest and enthusiasm in our current unit on European explorers; his participation has been truly impressive!

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Sam articulates quite well orally and we would like to see him achieve this same level of proficiency in his writing.  He needs to consistently utilize the writing tools we give him during writer's workshop lessons.  He has done this with his most recent efforts in our memoir unit and the results have been impressive.  Spelling is still a challenge for Sam, although we have seen improvement since the beginning of the school year.  Overall, we   feel that Sam has quite a cache of potential as a writer.  However, he will need to put in more effort and drive in order to unlock it.

We are happy to report that Sam is very engaged in book group meetings.  He loves to talk about the book we are reading.  Accordingly, we have noticed he has made some deep connections to the reading.  In addition, he is respectful of others when they are sharing ideas.  As a goal for Sam, we would like to see him apply the same amount of effort to his written assignments; it is clear that he has done the reading, but he has sometimes arrived to meeting with an incomplete or missing assignment.

teachers=Will Schaer, Devin Stanwyck, Meredith Stephenson;comments=

Sam is a bright, curious, and energetic child.  We have recently seen improvement in Sam’s ability to listen respectfully to others and raise his hand before calling out. Academically, Sam is capable, with writing posing the biggest challenge.  Sam has had some difficulty turning in homework, but he has recently improved and seems more focused on his academic pursuits.  We look forward to seeing this welcome trend continue.

We look forward to more of Sarah’s verve, dedication,  and strong work ethic during the coming semester; we know that they will serve her well!

Sarah is a joy to have in math group!  She is very engaged during lessons and works very diligently during both independent and group work times.  Even though Sarah's work is very often accurate, she sometimes shows some anxiety when she is not able to solve a problem correctly the first time.  However, once she is given a quick, reassuring check-in, she is quick to see her errors and does not make them a second time.  As it would surely benefit her, we would like Sarah to have even more confidence in herself as a mathematician, giving herself more credit for her abilities.  Sarah is always accountable for her assignments, shows her work on the page, and aims to please at all times.  We commend Sarah for her efforts in math; she is off to a very strong start in our division unit!

Simon is able to grasp and retain new social studies content quite well.  He learned a great deal about California’s geography, followed by the Chumash tribe, during our study of California Native Americans.  Simon was able to successfully apply unique cultural characteristics and integrate them into his “Chumash Story” writing piece.  More recently, Simon has learned about the relationship between the European explorers.  As a result, he is now able to recognize the impact of various historical events and analyze the resulting effects on a specific group of people.

Simon is a very strong mathematician.  He has a very thorough understanding of his number combinations and is always able to explain himself.  He is also very quick to catch the careless errors of others, but he does so in a very courteous manner.  Simon is consistently accountable for homework assignments and shows his work on the page.  In class, Simon participates very willingly and does a great job explaining his thought processes to his peers and his teachers.  As a result, his computations are largely accurate.  In the rare event that Simon is not able to arrive at the correct solution the first time, he perseveres until he does so.

At the beginning of the school year, we noticed it was quite difficult for Simon to begin a new writing piece, even after a mini-lesson had been given and directions had been provided.  We also wanted to see Simon taking more time during the pre-writing phase and self-editing his writing.  However, it must be mentioned that we have since seen some significant progress in those areas.  This progress began to make itself apparent during Simon’s research report on the Bald Eagle.  Simon has found spelling to be a consistent challenge; we have noticed improvement, however, and will continue to assist him in this area.   Overall, we are very proud of Simon’s progress as a writer!

Simon was a quiet, yet engaged member of book group.  His main strength was that he always showed up prepared and contributed regularly.  For the most part, he was able to follow the plot of the story and was able to cite specific events in the text.  Simon has shared with us that he sometimes leaves the completion of his weekly assignments until the night before they are due.  We have encouraged him to instead block out a bit of time each night, so that the task does not become overwhe;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Simon is a very warm, kind, and happy child.  He is quiet and soft-spoken in the classroom, but has a very cooperative nature, which is part of what draws his peers to him when opportunities for group interaction arise.  Simon is extremely receptive to any suggestions for revision, especially in regards to his writing; it is always a refreshing experience to conference with him.  These fine qualities, combined with a strong desire to please and succeed, make Simon a valued member of the community.

Throughout our unit on narratives, Zoe worked hard on her writing pieces.  We have consistently encouraged her to spend more time on self-editing.  We have noticed that Zoe has sometimes made the same errors twice, from one draft to another, even when edit marks are on the first draft.  Her biggest challenges are sentence breaks, as her writing is often full of run on sentences.  Her spelling also needs improvement; we would like to see her practicing her priority words a bit more.  We know and applaud the fact that Zoe can write with both imagery and a personal voice, but we need her to make writing mechanics a larger priority.  We know she can be successful in this regard, as we saw it evidenced in her wonderful California animal research report on the Monarch Butterfly. 

We have been enjoying our book group meetings with Zoe!  She has been very engaged and has seemed to relish the opportunity to talk about books she has read with her classmates.  On a couple of recent occasions, we have noticed that Zoe has gotten some of the events of the story confused and had trouble following the sequence of the events in the plot.  Once she had been given the correct informatio;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

It is clear that Zoe has an affinity for math.  She loves to participate in lessons and does not hesitate to show her work to her classmates and teachers.  On occasion, we have noticed that Zoe has had some initial difficulty finding her errors on the page, when she has made a mistake.  In reference to this tendency, we observed that she did encounter some difficulty during the multiplication unit when larger numbers were utilized in place value boxes; she also needed some review on the repeated subtraction method in our current division unit.  However, we want to give Zoe full credit for the work she has done since then, which has been very accurate and thorough.  Zoe works well with her math group peers and is an enthusiastic participant during both mini-lessons and group work times.

Zoe has demonstrated a high level of interest in our social studies units; this ultimately helped her to achieve success in our mapping unit, as well as complete her multi-faceted study of the Chumash Native Americans.  The first step involved a field trip to 'Humaliwo,' where Zoe got to see authentic replicas of dwellings and artifacts up close.  During the second step, Zoe got to create a replica of her own, in the form of a Chumash village scene.  Finally, she used all of her knowledge to create a 'day-in-the-life' account of a Chumash girl!  We are happy to add that Zoe is very focused during our lessons and does not hesitate to contribute to our discussions!

Quincy is responsible, friendly, and full of positive energy!  Quincy has found that she shares similar interests with other members of the class; she is happy and very engaged.  Quincy is also very responsible about completing her assignments and has a commendable work ethic.  She turns in well-done assignments on time, cares about her work, and uses good time management skills.

Esme is very insightful and loving. She is a compassionate child who knows how to use her words to express exactly what she is feeling or thinking. It is key that she uses her words instead of her body when she is frustrated. Esme is working on impulse control as she often calls out, gets off topic, and/or wants to talk to her friends at inappropriate times. She will also lose focus if a discussion last more than a couple minutes and will then want to lay on the floor. We would love to see her more engaged and actively participating. When she does raise her hand to say something it is usually accurate, so we know she is listening and making connections.  Esme benefits greatly from one on one support. She is producing much higher level work and learning to take her time. Without one on one support we see Esme struggle socially and academically. We are gradually taking steps to give Esme more time work independently. Esme has made connections in class and loves her peers. A goal for Esme is to not grab her friends or use her body in an agressive way. When she does so her peers become frustrated with her. She is amazingly kind and helpful to her teachers. Esme is also very friendly and likes to talk to new people whether they;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

Jennifer is a cooperative and helpful student.  She has made connections with everyone of her peers, but not consistent friendships.  We would like to suggest that she make a playdate with some friends in class, and have the playdate in afterschool. Jennifer works very hard at all her work.  Although she is putting in a great deal of effort, she is struggling academically.  Writing is the most challenging subject for her.  She has difficulty with spelling and sentence structure. She has not been able to tell or write a story in sequential order.  Jennifer needs to use a story web or her personal dictionary , in order to organize her ideas.  We conference with Jennifer to help her get her ideas on paper.  We are hopeful that she will improve during the second semester.  Jennifer also needs help with learning her math combinations to 20.  This is a matter of daily practice.  We are suggesting that Jennifer get help during the summer, so that she doesn't lose valuable time, in preparation for third grade. 

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

We have seen some improvement in Jennifer's reading fluency since she has started receiving help from Shahrzad, our reading resource teacher. Jennifer works very hard and is dedicated to becoming a better reader. We would recommend that she continue to receive support during the summer in order to keep moving her toward her goal. Jennifer struggles to write a clear and organized story. Her spelling and sentence structure are currently below grade level. We are working with Jennifer to organize her thinking by using a story web, a word list, her personal dictionary, and other strategies that will help her to complete a writing task with success.

teachers=Stefanie Grutman, Jessica Collins, Molly Kirkpatrick;skill_1178=4;skill_1180=4;skill_1181=5;skill_1182=2;skill_1179=4;skillspost=1178,1180,1181,1182,1179,1161,1162,1164,1165,1167,1154,1156,1157,1158,1159,1146,1187,1148,1183;skill_1161=4;skill_1162=4;skill_1164=4;skill_1165=4;skill_1167=4;skill_1154=5;skill_1156=4;skill_1157=4;skill_1158=4;skill_1159=4;skill_1146=4;skill_1187=4;skill_1148=5;skill_1183=4;comments=

Jennifer has large gaps in her understanding of number, and has difficulty applying addition and subtraction operations, with combinations up to 10.  She works very hard at trying to solve simple mathematical problems.  Jennifer needs to use counters, fingers, and other direct modeling tools.  She has particular difficulty with story problems, unable to understand what the problem is asking her to do.  Jennifer needs a great deal of support to learn new strategies to help her to understand how to work with numbers beyond 10. We strongly recommend that Jennifer get help this summer, in order to progress. We highly recommend that Jennifer uses the computer program, Xtra-Math, on a daily basis when she is in after school.  This program helps her to compute addition and subtraction problems at her level.  She competes with herself to raise her level.  She can use the computers in the library everyday.

;reader_notes=;notes=;status=1;submit=Save Section;

This semester, we have been studying an African coastal community and its similarities and differences to our own coastal community through the book series Anna Hibiscus and The No. 1 Car Spotter. In addition, we went into depth about the myths and stereotypes of Native Americans, past and present, and recognized their contributions to American culture. It is difficult, in certain ways, to assess Jennifer's understanding of our social studies curriculum.  She does not readily participate in class discussions, and often times, her expressive thought processes are not organized or sequential. However, when we are able to have a more intimate conversation with Jennifer, it becomes evident that she is, in fact, grasping concepts. We will continue to encourage Jennifer to express her thinking, even if she is reticent to do so. We will support her in attending to the topic being discussed and to take the necessary risk to participate.
